Questa mattina però mi sono accorto che cercando di scaricare la posta di quell'indirizzo da un altro client la sincronizzazione non avveniva e non scaricava nulla, mentre ieri invece era regolare. Facendo altre prove su Thunderbird avevo notato che da quell'indirizzo scaricava sempre e solo una email e sempre la stessa. Allora sono andato sulla webmail di Aruba, ho cancellato quella email, dopodiché ho riprovato a scaricare la posta da Thunderbird ed ha scaricato regolarmente tutte le email che erano presenti sul server di Aruba. Non so dire per quale motivo quella email bloccava la procedura, tra l'altro era una email da un indirizzo sicuro. Meno male che la cosa si è risolta positivamente e sono felice che non fosse un problema di Thunderbird (credo!). Grazie comunque dei suggerimenti.

content:
I think the vertical separators of the Folder Pane Columns are not visible in your setup. In the attached picture you should see a separator above the green dot. Hover on the separator to turn the cursor into a double arrow, then click and drag the separator left or right to make the column width show the numbers in the columns.

The separators are faint 'by design', but might be invisible depending on the contrast or brightness of your monitor.

content:
Thunderbird does not make any connection to the internet when you click a link in Windows. It simply passes the link to Windows for it to do something with it. Windows makes the connection that it is a web URL and passes it to the default web browser for action.

Third party antivirus programs have a long history of causing these sorts of issues, especially just after you install or upgrade Thunderbird.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Yes, - settings>Privacy&security - click 'saved passwords' and then 'show passwords' - highlight BOTH rows of your account (incoming and outgoing servers) - delete the two rows. - now when you click to receive messages, you will be prompted for password.

Another way to check if a message has been replied to is to right-click, Open Message In Conversation. It only works one message at a time, but it's a quick alternative to searching the Sent folder.

creator: sfhowes

content:
re :I've tried to copy it back into my imap.gmail.com folder, but nothing populates for the deleted folders when I open TB.

That's because Thunderbird starts up and the first thing it does is access the gmail server to check and update the gmail imap account. As the folders/labels do not exist on server they get removed from the imap account. Imap accounts can only show what is on server.

But it is possible to upload emails back onto the server, but Thunderbird has to be started and connected to server first and you need those emails accessible in 'Local Folders' mail account.

re:I have a copy of the .sbd file that still shows all the .msf files The .msf files are only index files. They do not contain emails. Do you also have mbox files (no extension) - these files contain emails? For a .sbd folder to display it would need an mbox no extension file of same name.

So if you have - this is an example: mbox no extension file called 'Orders' and also an 'Orders.sbd' folder and If the 'Orders.sbd' folder contains mbox no extension files.

  • Exit Thunderbird now - this is important.
  • Copy the mbox no extension file called 'Orders' and also an 'Orders.sbd' folder
  • paste them into the 'Local Folders' mail account located in the 'Mail' folder.


Then when you restart Thunderbird, access 'Local Folders' mail account and you will see a new folder called 'Orders' and it should contain subfolders. Those folders should also contain emails.

  • Recreate the required folders in the imap gmail account.
  • Subscribe to see those folders.
  • Copy batches of highlighted emails from the 'Local Folders' > 'Orders' folder/subfolders
  • then Paste them into the newly created imap account folder.

This will then get updates to the server.

If you do not have mbox files then you do not have emails. The only alternative is to create everything on the server first.

  • Logon to webmail account via a browser.
  • Create the various folders/labels and make sure they are set to 'show in imap'
  • Access 'All Mail' and move relevant emails into the various labels you have created.
  • Then in Thunderbird, subscribe to see those new folders and subfolders.
  • Check Account Settings > Synchronisation & Storage for gmail imap account
  • If you have already selected to 'keep messages in all folders for this account on computer.....'
  • click on 'Advanced' button and make sure all folders and subfolders are selected so a full downloaded copy can occur.
  • Also select 'Synchronise all messages locally regardless of age'

creator: MattAuSupport

content:
in account settings > Server settings.

Just be aware many modern IMAP mail server use push notification to notify new mail so checking in largely irrelevant. Note also that setting to less than 10 minutes can lead to some servers simply refusing connections so your reduction actually leads to an increase as only every second or third connection attempt gets mail. Additionally on slower, or saturated, internet connections with an antivirus mail scanner active, a fetch of mail may not complete in less than 5 minutes, so you never actually get mail completed before the next overtakes it. Sometime the result is no mail from either attempt, others it is duplicate mail and yet others it just works.
creator: MattAuSupport

Please check the following:

Exit Thunderbird Access Firewall which maybe controlled by your anti-vius product. Set Thunderbird as an allowed program, so ports do not get blocked.

What Anti-virus are you using? Suggest you access Anti-Virus product and switch off scanning of outgoing mail just in case the Anti-Virus is being a pain and causing an interuption in sending.
